p: Isoetes are considered rare living fossils. With the rapid development of the economy resulting in habitat degradation, wild populations have declined dramatically. Thus far, resource utilization of Isoetes has yet to be reported, especially for the specific species, Isoetes sinensis Palmer. I. sinensis was a common species in the wetlands of An’hui, Jiangxi, Jiangsu, and Zhejiang Provinces before 1980. In the last 20 years, this species has all but disappeared [ 9]. Due to this dramatic decline, I. sinensis has been considered a critically endangered, first-class protected plant in China since 1999 [ 10– 12]. Fortunately, our lab has propagated tens of thousands of I. sinensis by way of creative spore propagation, which has allowed for the development of Isoetes and its continued use in present and future research.
